history.content:
Finish your HSS reqs. You can easily finish all/half of them by taking online classes at community colleges.

Also build an app. It doesn't have to do anything special, but it will teach you a lot. Make it full-stack. If you're good at backend, work on visualizations and UI. If you've got a strong frontend background try sharpening your database and runtime skills.

Apply for summer course staff! I did that last summer and really enjoyed it. I made a lot of friends and learned a lot. A lot of people take a class as well or work (I worked in a research lab... a job I found through handshake during finals week)

Finish your HSS reqs. You can easily finish all/half of them by taking online classes at community colleges.  

Also build an app. It doesn't have to do anything special, but it will teach you a lot. Make it full-stack. If you're good at backend, work on visualizations and UI. If you've got a strong frontend background try sharpening your database and runtime skills.

children.subject:
Anything is better than nothing (: It's more to show that you take initiative in your learning; also industry work is quite different from the homeworks/labs/projects we do in school.

Something you would use or maybe something you think can help out someone you know would be good. But for your first side project, it's kind of overwhelming to deal with all the info out on the web so I would recommend finding a tutorial (and sticking to it) first for whatever stack you decide to work with (i.e Flask, Django, Rails, etc). Just choose one - it doesn't matter very much, since you can pick up more very quickly later. Finish the tutorial, then use what you learned to build something you actually want to do.

I think it's quite hard to force yourself to do side projects unless you're really passionate about tech/coding (even though I have lots of ideas I often prefer listening to music or watching shows LOL), so if you can find a friend to work together that might be more fun! Something else I personally did was online courses (Udemy, etc). (However it is still very hard to convince yourself to do these... lol).
Any ideas for what kind of apps? @student answer
Thanks! Where have people found the most luck with finding research?

URAP is pretty competitive for CS research since a million people apply (like most things at Berkeley lol).

 Try emailing grad students. They are usually happy for a few people to come help them out.
Take a summer course while working on course staff, or work in a research lab! You'll do an internship next summer and work for most of your life, so why not try teaching or research?

history.content: What do people recommend doing in the summer if you don't get an internship? I am a sophomore in EECS for reference
history.subject: Best summer options if no internship?
